moves.1. d4 d5 2. Bf4 e6 3. Nf3 Nc6: I consider this almost a mistake by black, because it blocks the c pawn, the black's mobile part of the game.
moves.4. e3 Nf6 5. h3: To provide an escape way for my beloved dsb in h2. It's kind a waste of time. The alternative was to avoid this escape taking the Nf3 to e5. This leads to NxN, dxN, and another game. I wanted to play for this one.
moves.5... Be7: The Nc6 is a real can tap for black. Bd6 is another way to see the situation. I would have answered Ne5.
moves.6. Nbd2: I don't plan c4, this is to block the black's dsb with c3.
moves.6... O-O 7. g4: This is my plan: to attack the kingside.
moves.7... h6 8. Ne5: Thematic. I give black the chance to get rid off his black knight, but I open the way for the queen to h5.
moves.9. h4: Now g4 is protected, and I can press the kingside. This move also avoids the symmetric queen's invasion in h4, once the Nf6 has flew.
moves.9... Bxe5 10. dxe5: Now, black can play d4 the next one, his best chance to expand. But I have a tempo (if black decides not to sac the knight for the attack).
moves.10... Ne4 11. Bd3: This also prevents d4. Now, black should go NxN, and after QxN, d4 is playable (so I should have played something else!). But without the knight, I feel my position would be defendable.
moves.11... f5: Trying to block the kingside with this well-known structure. If I take ep, exf6, his pieces suddenly get to life, and I think it was more precise...
moves.12. g5: ...because black cannot h5 or Qxh5. I don't exchange the knight because it would make me lose a precious tempo retiring the bishop from there.
moves.13. hxg5: ...being the h column my real target.
moves.13... Nxg5 14. Qh5: Now the piece is lost, or it has to go back.
moves.14... Ne4: It goes back, sensibly. But what a tempo loss!
moves.15. Be2: Instead of going like a boy after the check, I thought that it would have been more accurate to get the bishop into the fry, overlooking Qh7+, Kf7, Rg1, Rg8, Qg6+, Ke7, NxN and then is up to black to find an answer for Bg5+, taking the queen.
moves.15... Nb4: Well, black is dreaming about attacks (or free himself a little), and this just gives me a move to...
moves.16. O-O-O: And what about Nxf2, forking the two rooks? Don't worry: the attack I have is more than enough.
moves.18... Ke7 19. Bg5+: Which is better? Ok, I'm two pawns down but... who cares? But this was just an oversight: Qxg7+ and mate on the next. I miserabily failed to see it.
moves.19... Kd7: Now it's too late: the king escapes and it will become a little nightmare to catch it.
moves.20. Qxg7+ Kc6 21. Bxd8: A queen is a queen. No brilliant mate on sight, sigh!
moves.21... Rxd8 22. Rh4: A way to mobilize my pieces. A rook on the queenside and I "must" get this king...
moves.22... Nxd1 23. Rxb4 Nxe3: Aha... and the mate isn't any near! This is becoming annoyant. And after all, I am only +2. The fact that black pieces are cashed in gives me the edge, but... I see free pawns coming in.
moves.24. c4: I'll give him another, but I have to try to open the cage the king is in.
moves.24... a5: Very good by black. I just don't want to retire my rook, no with my advantage.
moves.25... exd5 26. Qf6+ Kc5: Ok, I can't see the mate. Can you?
moves.27... Kc6 28. Be8+: I can always retire the rook. I just want to avoid it, be smarter. I'm not sure it was the right idea, because if Rb3, black can't play d4 because of Bf3+, Nd5, Rc3+, Kb5, Qc5+, and mate on the next.
moves.29... Kc5: Nothing better that I found. Probably Rxb7 would have helped, but I wasn't so sure.
moves.31... Rxd7 32. Qe6+: Black can even think about some Re6, exR, axR, but for QxN.
moves.32... Kc5: Now I do have to retire my rook, or exchange it with him. The exchange was good, but I play for fun.
moves.33. Rb3: What happens now? Black still have to protect two pieces, and sure he will prefer the rook.
moves.34. Rxe3: Now my advantage is so strong that I can play without... well... let's see...
moves.34... d4: Nb3+, Kb5. Can you see the mate? I can't.
moves.35... Kb6 36. Rb3+ Ka7: Still no mate. Qc5+, b6 and... Nc4, and...
moves.37... b6 38. Nc4: Aha, now the knight sac would be the definitive element to win.
moves.38... Rd7d5 39. Qc6 Rc5: Can you believe that? This happens to me for playing lightly.
moves.40. Qe6: I was in a really delicate situation, all of a sudden, wiht all my advantage.
moves.40... b5: Interesting. No, I cannot accept that, there must be a way...
moves.41. Kd2: Qe7, RxN+, and then saves the other rook. Holdable, but... wasn't I safer with this one?
moves.42... c3+: Black is playing well, and I am shaking.
moves.43. bxc3 dxc3+ 44. Kc2: I expected Rd2+, Kb3, c2... and I could have resigned (or accept the game with a new black queen on the board, trying to give it for a rook...). My queen is in a horrible position.
moves.44... Rdd5: Black make here his worst mistake, assuming the previous line was correct. Still, it is not easy to find a way to the win. I can Qxf5, Rxe5, etc...
moves.45. Rxc3: Uff, I must take the pawn undoubtely. But not with his rook on a column farther from my king than the d. Now, he can easily go Rxe5, and then my queen must run and Re2+, and I have Kd3 and I am saved. If 46. Qxf5 instead, Rxe5, Qf2! pinning the other rook!
moves.45... Rdxe5 46. Qd7: No place to go to cover Re2+. I will have to lose another pawn (a2)
moves.47... Rxc3+ 48. Kxc3: Ok, this is good for me, of course. But the situation is not as clear as before.
moves.48... Rc5+ 49. Kb3 Kb6 50. Qe6+: I will have to work a lot to get it. I couldn't imagine this was a decisive move.
moves.50... c6: Blacke thinks to close in a fortress and resist as he can, but overlooked a wonderful and unsuspected situation on the next move.
moves.51. Qe3: Black is in an almost-zugwang position.
moves.52... Kb6 53. Ka3: A waiting move, because now the black king cannot return to b5.
moves.54. Qxf4 Rc3+ 55. Kb2 Rc4: Black had a blackout here, and so did I. I couldn't believe this rook was unprotected, and, with few seconds left, played the "more interesting" move.
moves.56. Qb8+ Kc5 57. Qa7+: ...grabbing another pawn, and with it all black's hopes.
